p: In Ayurvedic, Sinhala, Chinese, and African traditional medicine, various parts of S. alata have shown diverse therapeutic activities in diseases control. In northern Nigeria, the stem, leaf, and root decoctions is used in treatment of wound, skin and respiratory tract infection, burns, diarrhoea, and constipation [ 41, 42]. Also, in the south-western regions, leaf decoction serves as an antidote to body and abdominal pain, stress, and toothache [ 43]. It also cures dermal infections, convulsion, and as purgative [ 44, 45]. In Egypt, the leaf decoction was observed to be used as a bowel stimulant to stimulate peristaltic shrinkages and decrease water absorption from the colon in attempt to prevent constipation [ 46]. In Cameroon, the stem, bark, and leaves were reported to be used as a remedy for gastroenteritis, hepatitis, ringworm, and dermal infections [ 47].
